awd_titl_txt: Planning IUCRC Northeastern University: Center for Cloud and Data Center-Scale Computing (DCSC)
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud computing has become pervasive in recent years, with a large fraction of enterprise computing moving to the cloud, and entire categories of new enterprises exclusively using the cloud rather than on-premises servers. Yet to date innovation in cloud computing has been difficult for members of organizations - whether academic or industrial - which are not one of a small number of large cloud providers. Many advances have depended on not only access to large-scale computing environments, but also to users and their applications, to (a) inform research with data on what problems to target, and (b) evaluate how proposed technologies might address real problems or enable new uses. The Center for Data Center Scale Computing (DCSC) seeks to increase the pace of innovation in this field by making the prerequisites for such research available to faculty and industrial collaborators. 

DCSC seeks to harness the computing demand within participating academic institutions to both inform research and provide a path for evaluation and translation into practice. At the same time, the Center will take advantage of open-source licensing to allow close collaboration between university researchers and industrial partners, allowing engineering and system-building on a level difficult to achieve solely within a university environment. Particular areas of focus of the Center at Northeastern University include data storage for the cloud, including emerging storage technologies and storage for Big Data and machine learning, and the use of new accelerator technologies.

Broader impacts of this work will come in part from development of new technologies for cloud systems, storage, and platforms, especially those targeting use cases outside of the main public cloud markets, such as academic, research, and hybrid clouds; the impact of these developments will be amplified by the wide-spread use of cloud computing. Graduate students will be involved in high-quality research projects, and both graduate and undergraduate students in support roles will receive training in skills of value to industry. In recruiting students for Center positions we will work closely with Northeastern's ALIGN program and its diversity efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the proposed IUCRC, the Center for Systems Research at Scale (i-Scale), is to explore the unique challenges of computing systems at large scale, across software, networking, and hardware layers. This research will be performed in collaboration with partners from across the corresponding industry, motivating and informing research in a field where key innovations have often come from outside academia. i-Scale will seek to spark research innovation by not only encouraging close and regular contact between researchers and engineering-level representatives of member companies, but by leveraging access to institutional clouds used by a diverse range of researchers and academic users at the two university, providing access to operational details unavailable in many environments.

Activities and outcomes for the Planning Grant include:

Industry outreach: Outreach began as part of the NSF IUCRC boot camp, and continued through the planning period. Outreach began with existing PI contacts and members of the Mass Open Cloud Alliance, reaching next to secondary contacts by following the Lean Launchpad methodology from the IUCRC boot camp. This process not only helped recruit potential members to participate in the planning process, but helped refine our goals and value proposition, resulting in significant changes to the proposed Center mission.

Covid-related delays: An in-person planning meeting was originally scheduled for Spring 2020, and was delayed multiple times, as companies in this sector were slow to return to the office and to resume authorizing in-person travel. During this period we maintained contact with potential members, recruiting several new ones while losing a few to personnel changes.

Planning workshop: this was held on March 21 and 22 at Boston and Northeastern Universities respectively. Of the 50+ companies and organizations contacted, a total of 37 representatives from 32 organizations attended, including IBM, Dell, Lenovo, Red Hat, Microsoft, Google, Amazon AWS, and others. Total attendance including faculty and students was 98.

10 projects were pitched as part of the workshop, with projects focusing on storage, monitoring, telemetry and management, and hardware acceleration. We conducted surveys to collect feedback after each presentation, provided faculty responses, and on the second day held a wide-ranging discussion with industry attendees on the goals and directions for the Center.

Submission: The Center MOU was negotiated between Northeastern and Boston Universities, industry commitments were solicited, and a Phase I proposal was submitted in June with 8 supporting letters of commitment.

Modified by: Peter Desnoyers
